Award.AwardTitle: Role of Phages in Structuring Bacterial Communities: Ciona Intestinalis as a Model Organism
Award.AbstractNarration:
The animal gut hosts a complex community of specially-adapted bacteria that interface directly with the host epithelial cells and fundamentally affect host health and nutrition. Because gut bacteria play such vital roles in host health, a detailed understanding of how bacteria colonize the gut and how biological and biophysical factors affect the stability and longevity of their symbiotic existence with the host is of enormous significance. One often overlooked factor that may play a significant role in structuring gut-associated bacterial communities is the presence of viruses, specifically phages (viruses that infect bacteria). The investigators have developed a simple marine invertebrate model system (the sea squirt Ciona intestinalis) that affords the opportunity to dissect numerous aspects of host:bacteria symbiosis, such as initial colonization, effects of feeding and digestion, and interactions with the host immune system. In this project, they will test the hypothesis that phages serve important roles in shaping overall bacterial community structure through their ability to break apart specific hosts, thereby releasing dissolved organics and facilitating gene transfer among hosts, and driving microbial evolution. By carefully examining phage-bacteria interactions both in vitro and within the gut of the sea squirt, they will gain unprecedented insight into the effects of phages on bacterial communities living within animal guts. This research will benefit society by exploring the promise of phages for remodeling complex microbial communities, which has important implications for human health, bioremediation, and ecosystem restoration projects. The investigators will develop an outreach program that encourages high school students to undertake mentored science fair projects encompassing microbial ecology concepts and provide hands-on training in molecular microbiology techniques. To reach a distinct target audience, they will also run microbial ecology modules for Girl Scouts, Girls Incorporated, and the University of South Florida's Oceanography Camp for Girls.

To examine the roles of phages in shaping the overall structure and function of bacterial communities, the investigators will accomplish three specific research objectives: 1) characterize phage diversity in the Ciona gut using culture-based and culture independent methods, 2) dissect phage-bacteria interactions in vitro and determine if phages can modify bacterial community (microbiome) structure in experimentally colonized Ciona, and 3) culture Ciona in both the presence and absence of phages in the water to determine the effects of phage presence on gut microbiomes and host physiology. As a filter-feeding sessile organism, Ciona directly interfaces with the marine environment and encounters a continuous stream of microbes that can potentially colonize or influence its gut flora. Previous work with adult, field-harvested, Ciona indicated that a consistent, "core" microbiome dominates their gut. Additionally, they have successfully cultured various members of the core gut microbiome, isolated phages for some of these bacteria, and are studying the process of extracellular biofilm formation by these bacteria on artificially constructed matrices that resemble the surface of the gut epithelium in the presence and absence of phages. Ciona is a highly tractable experimental system that can be grown under predominantly sterile conditions, allowing experimental control of of nearly every aspect of the symbiotic conversation between host, bacteria, and phages. The results of this work have the transformative potential of redefining our understanding of the factors that shape the establishment and maintenance of stable, host-associated, bacterial communities and in turn affect the physiology of the host itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is now understood that most living things host complex communities of microbes, most of which are bacteria. These mostly non-pathogenic bacteria can form complex ecosystems shaping animal growth, health, and defense against infections. Importantly, all living things (even microbes) can become infected by viruses. Bacteriophages, or phages for short, are viruses that specifically target, recognize, and infect bacteria. Because bacteria form such important relationships with their hosts, and serve critical roles in the "microbiome" of animals, infection by phages can exert enormous influence on microbiome stability and, thus, on host health. 

Microbiome (and "virome") sciences benefit substantially from simple animals that allow us to model and study the biology and ecology of these host-microbe interactions. For example, phage therapies can target antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections and can also be useful for modulating therapeutic levels of live microbes used to treat disease, either with conventional or engineered probiotics. Similar microbial resources are also necessary for the continued development of sustainable food production. Thus, the basic sciences, particularly focused on studies utilizing simpler model systems, can help us discover fundamental pathways that are crucial to understanding disease etiologies in humans. 

The marine invertebrate sea squirt, Ciona intestinalis type A (now recognized as Ciona robusta), is a chordate, which means it is distantly related to vertebrates, like humans. Despite being a filter-feeder that comes into contact with a continuous stream of microbe-rich seawater, Ciona can maintain a remarkably stable gut microbiome (Dishaw et al, Plos One 2014). This project utilized this simple model system to explore the roles of phages in (re-) shaping gut microbiomes. We hypothesized that colonization of the gut begins at the onset of feeding, and that lifelong host-microbiome partnerships become established early but remain susceptible to external perturbations. 

To study the role of phages in the gut microbiome, we cultured almost 100 different strains of bacteria that are native to the Ciona gut, and these cultured strains are important for conducting laboratory experiments to study phage infection. We were also successful in developing a method to culture Ciona under germ-free conditions, which allowed us to experimentally transplant specific bacteria-phage combinations from the culture dish to the gut of a live animal. Experimental outcomes were then studied by observing easily distinguishable changes visible within the tiny, transparent, juveniles. The presence of phage dramatically influences not only abundance, but niche settlement among bacteria colonizing the gut. We found that Ciona maintains a gut virome that is distinct from the virome of the surrounding seawater and contains temporally-stable members (Leigh et al, Virus Research 2018). This virome is dominated by double stranded DNA tailed phages (Order Caudovirales); unique viral communities were also found in distinct niches of the gut, paralleling compartmentalization of gut bacterial communities. The virome also possesses a very large and diverse community of small, single-stranded DNA viruses of the Microviridae family, some of which suggest the presence of intracellular bacteria within the Ciona gut (Creasy et al, Viruses 2018). We also found evidence that prophages, or phages that are integrated into bacterial genomes, are likely prevalent within the gut of Ciona. Prophages have the capacity to shape bacterial behaviors and fitness; many of these phages are inducible by a variety of stressors and their active viral counterparts may be infectious towards other members of the microbiome. Defining the complex roles for prophages in shaping the gut microbiome remains an active area of investigation. And finally, we discovered that a secreted immune effector protein from the Ciona gut, known as the variable immunoglobulin-like domain chitin-binding protein (or VCBP), interacts with bacteria, shapes biofilm formation, and impacts bacteria-phage interactions.

This project leveraged an interdisciplinary approach to study the complexity of phage communities within natural and experimental microbial communities, and was responsible for training and supporting numerous undergraduate interns and research assistants, three graduate students, and one post-doctoral associate. To reach our neighboring communities, both Dishaw and Breitbart labs performed outreach events at the Saint Petersburg Science Festival, a community event that serves over 12,000 people. Examples of our special displays presented during this award period are as follows: "Symbiosis in the Sea," which discussed the critical roles that microbes (bacteria and viruses) play in animal ecology and well-being. Another display was titled "Phage Heroes: Protecting the World from Evil Bacteria." Mya Breitbart was a featured speaker at several 'Pint of Science' events disseminating research results to the general public, and was recently selected as Girls Incorporated of Pinellas 'STEM Woman of the Year' in recognition for her numerous outreach activities. Both labs take part in teaching the annual Oceanography Camp for Girls at USF and for the past 4 years, each lab included unique phage-bacterial ecology modules. Breitbart also works with local Girl Scouts and Girls Incorporated chapters to inspire young women to pursue science.
